articles.headline: ‘Putin Is a Fool’: Intercepted Calls Reveal Russian Army in Disarray
articles.snippet: In phone calls to friends and relatives at home, Russian soldiers gave damning insider accounts of battlefield failures and civilian executions, excoriating their leaders just weeks into the campaign to take Kyiv.
articles.abstract: In phone calls to friends and relatives at home, Russian soldiers gave damning insider accounts of battlefield failures and civilian executions, excoriating their leaders just weeks into the campaign to take Kyiv.
articles.lead_paragraph: In phone calls to friends and relatives at home, Russian soldiers gave damning insider accounts of battlefield failures and civilian executions, excoriating their leaders just weeks into the campaign to take Kyiv.
articles.byline: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Evan Hill, Rumsey Taylor, Matt Ruby, Aleksandra Koroleva and Ksenia Nesterenko

articles.headline: Pound’s Swoon Echoes Declines in British Power, Past and Present
articles.snippet: The Bank of England had to step in Wednesday after markets deemed a new government economic plan unwise, but the pound has been on a longer slide.
articles.abstract: The Bank of England had to step in Wednesday after markets deemed a new government economic plan unwise, but the pound has been on a longer slide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Britain’s pound coin — rimmed in nickel and brass with an embossed image of Queen Elizabeth II at the center — could always be counted on to be significantly more valuable than the dollar.

articles.headline: Sabotaged Pipelines and a Mystery: Who Did It? (Was It Russia?)
articles.snippet: An attack on gas lines under the Baltic Sea exposes the vulnerability of an already jittery Europe. Some officials suggested Moscow was to blame, but with little evidence, others urge caution.
articles.abstract: An attack on gas lines under the Baltic Sea exposes the vulnerability of an already jittery Europe. Some officials suggested Moscow was to blame, but with little evidence, others urge caution.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Two days after a pair of explosions under the Baltic Sea apparently ruptured giant natural gas pipelines from Russia to Germany, the consensus hardened on Wednesday that it had been an act of sabotage, as the European Union and several European governments labeled it an attack and demanded an investigation.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Ian Bludgeons Southwest Florida With Devastating Winds and Storm Surge
articles.snippet: A huge stretch of coastline from Naples to Sarasota appeared severely affected by lapping brown waves that drowned streets, homes and cars as frightened residents sought refuge.
articles.abstract: A huge stretch of coastline from Naples to Sarasota appeared severely affected by lapping brown waves that drowned streets, homes and cars as frightened residents sought refuge.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Hurricane Ian bludgeoned its way through southwestern Florida on Wednesday as one of the most powerful storms to ever strike the state, bringing fierce winds, unrelenting rains and drastic inundations to coastal communities that were overtaken by the surging waters of the Gulf of Mexico.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei, Lauren Sweeney, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Russian Proxies in Ukraine Push Moscow to Annex Occupied Regions
articles.snippet: The requests lent an air of formality to a process condemned by the West. They followed sham referendums in four regions in Ukraine that purported to put voters’ stamp of approval on joining Russia.
articles.abstract: The requests lent an air of formality to a process condemned by the West. They followed sham referendums in four regions in Ukraine that purported to put voters’ stamp of approval on joining Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In a display of pageantry intended to give Moscow’s land grab a veneer of legitimacy, Russian proxy officials in occupied areas of Ukraine appealed to President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday to annex the regions.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney

articles.headline: Britain’s Gamble on Tax Cuts Has Economists Warning of Past Mistakes
articles.snippet: Liz Truss, Britain’s new prime minister, defended her plan in the face of stiff criticism from the International Monetary Fund and others.
articles.abstract: Liz Truss, Britain’s new prime minister, defended her plan in the face of stiff criticism from the International Monetary Fund and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: A stunning rebuke from the International Monetary Fund this week underscored one of the biggest risks of the new British government’s plan to slash taxes on high earners: It could exacerbate rapid inflation and destabilize markets at a precarious economic moment.

articles.headline: Even as Oil Prices Ease, U.S. Keeps Tapping Strategic Reserve
articles.snippet: The administration’s move has brought down gasoline prices. Some experts say continued withdrawals could test the nation’s energy security.
articles.abstract: The administration’s move has brought down gasoline prices. Some experts say continued withdrawals could test the nation’s energy security.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, President Biden has overseen the largest sale of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve ever, to ease prices at the gasoline pump.

articles.headline: China’s ‘Absurd’ Covid Propaganda Stirs Rebellion
articles.snippet: The use of propaganda in the country has been on overdrive in the pandemic, with some Chinese citizens arguing the language has bordered on “nonsense.”
articles.abstract: The use of propaganda in the country has been on overdrive in the pandemic, with some Chinese citizens arguing the language has bordered on “nonsense.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “We have won the great battle against Covid!”
